channel.title: Golang Weekly
channel.description: A weekly newsletter about the Go programming language

item.title: The talks from GopherCon UK 2025 go live
item.description:
#‚Äã571 ‚Äî September 24, 2025

Read the Web¬†Version

Go Weekly

Go's Support for Valgrind Instrumentation ‚Äî Valgrind is a commonly used instrumentation framework for creating tools that can do profiling and detect various memory management and threading bugs in apps. This still-experimental support for Valgrind in Go opens up a wealth of extra opportunities for low-level diagnostics for Go¬†programs.

Roland Shoemaker

üí° This Hacker News discussion has more details, including a comment from the author of the pull request/CL about what the support was initially intended¬†for.

Go Event-Driven: From the Watermill Creators ‚Äî Mi≈Çosz and Robert from Three Dots Labs are launching the next edition of their hands-on training. It teaches the tricky parts of event-driven systems such as the outbox pattern, message ordering, and sagas. Don't sleep on this one. Opens autumn¬†2025.

Three Dots Labs sponsor

‚ñ∂¬†¬†Twenty Talks from GopherCon UK 2025 ‚Äî A YouTube playlist containing the just-uploaded talks from last month‚Äôs London-based Go conference. Every talk is technical and deep, but you might particularly enjoy Daniel Marti‚Äôs What‚Äôs Coming in Go 1.25 , Roland Shoemaker talking about Go security , or Emily Achieng talking about Go module hygiene and keeping your go.sum and go.mod files in¬†check.

GopherCon UK

Practical Networking Patterns in Go ‚Äî A new section of the on-going ‚ÄúGo Optimization Guide‚Äùfeaturing 13 guides to the various topics involved in building scalable, networked Go apps ‚Äî including benchmarking, how to achieve ‚Äòmassive concurrency‚Äô, diagnostics, transport protocols, low-level tuning, and¬†more.

Alexander Stavonin

IN BRIEF:

  • The latest Go developer survey is open for just one more week, closing next Tuesday, September 30. You can take it here.

  • WebAssembly/WASM is an increasingly common compilation target for Go, so it's neat to see the WebAssembly 3.0 standard is now 'live'(and already ships with most browsers) with various features that should improve interoperability in the long-term, including garbage collection, tail calls, and exception handling.

  • The IEEE has published a list of the top 'programming languages' in 2025 with Go coming in at number¬†10.

Building Conway‚Äôs Game of Life with raylib-go ‚Äî Just a bit of fun. Here‚Äôs the resulting¬†code.

Tim Little

Kubernetes CPU Limits and Go ‚Äî An update of an article from 2024. Go‚Äôs runtime doesn‚Äôt inherently know that it‚Äôs running within a Kubernetes environment, so there are tweaks you can make. However, also bear in mind Go 1.25‚Äôs changes to GOMAXPROCS‚Äôs¬†defaults.

William Kennedy

üìÑ How Fast is Go? Simulating Millions of Particles on a Smart TV ‚Äì ‚ÄúGo is able to simulate 2.5 million particles at 60 fps while sending data at 30 fps to in theory over 300 clients, maybe even a¬†thousand.‚ÄùDavid Gerrells

üìÑ Making a Cross-Platform Game using Pion and WebRTC Datachannels ‚Äì The current setup has some drawbacks, but there‚Äôs a lot of potential here if you want to explore¬†it. Srayan Jana

üìÑ CSRF Protection via Headers in Go 1.25 Jon Calhoun

üõ† Code & Tools

ü§ñGoMLX: An Accelerated Machine Learning Framework for Go ‚Äî A set of machine learning libraries and tools designed to act as a sort-of Go alternative to PyTorch or TensorFlow. Despite the name, it‚Äôs not related to Apple‚Äôs MLX framework and is actually Linux-only for now. It does, however, open up the opportunity to train and use ML models directly from Go, as Eli Bendersky explains in this introductory¬†post.

GoMLX Team

TableWriter 1.1: Render Rich Text-Based Tables ‚Äî A flexible library for rendering tabular data to ASCII, Unicode, Markdown, HTML, or for colorized terminals. The README is packed with¬†examples.

Oleku Konko

Secure Your Agentic Apps with Auth for GenAI ‚Äî Secure your agentic apps with features like User Authentication for AI agents, Token Vault, and more with Auth0‚Äôs Auth for GenAI (exclusively in Developer¬†Preview).

Auth0 sponsor

Gojekyll: A Fast Go Implementation of Jekyll ‚Äî Jekyll is a very popular Ruby-powered static site generator ‚Äì this is a ‚Äòpartially-compatible‚Äô clone that boasts enhanced performance and portability by being written in¬†Go. Worth a look if you have a Jekyll-powered site but want to remove Ruby from your¬†stack.

Oliver Steele and Daniil Gentili

Valgo 0.7: An Expressive Validator Library ‚Äî Type-safe and extensible validator library built upon generics. Rules are written in functions and not in struct tags. v0.7 adds new validation helpers and type-safe validators that remove codegen and width-specific¬†types.

Cohesive Stack

Fibratus: Windows Kernel Exploration and Observability Tool ‚Äî Now pitched as a ‚Äúadversary tradecraft detection, protection, and hunting‚Äùtool, Fibratus captures system events, such as file I/O and network requests, and scans memory, so you can gain insight into what apps are up to. GitHub¬†repo.

Fibratus

Go Allocations Explorer Extension for VSCode ‚Äî Uses your benchmarks to identify and list the allocations inside VS¬†Code.

Matt Sherman

  • purego 0.9 ‚Äì Library for calling C functions from Go without Cgo, now with support for Objective-C blocks and linux/loong64 .

  • k6 1.3 ‚Äì Modern Go + JavaScript-powered load testing tool.¬†(Homepage.)

  • MCP-Go 0.40 ‚Äì An implementation of the Model Context Protocol¬†(MCP).

  • NATS.go 1.46 ‚Äì Go client for the NATS messaging¬†system.

  • BillionMail 4.5 ‚Äì Go-powered email campaign¬†platform.

  • golangci-lint 2.5 ‚Äì A faster way to run Go¬†linters.

  • go-github 75.0 ‚Äì GitHub v3 API client¬†library.

  • Gin 1.11 ‚Äì Popular HTTP web¬†framework.

item.title: The latest Go developer survey is open
item.description:
#‚Äã570 ‚Äî September 17, 2025

Read the Web¬†Version

Go Weekly

Memory Allocation in Go ‚Äî The efficient allocation and management of memory is a fundamental part of what makes Go programs reliable and responsive and, luckily, Go abstracts away most of the complexity. If you want to know what‚Äôs going on under the hood, though, this is a fantastic, rich, diagrammed¬†exploration.

Nghia Nguyen

Go Beyond with Frontend and Fullstack Engineering Courses ‚Äî Get $100 off an annual Frontend Masters membership, and gain access to professional courses on Go, TypeScript, Cloud Infrastructure, AWS, React, and much much more. Sale ends soon¬†‚Üí

Frontend Masters sponsor

It's Survey Time! The 2025 Go Developer Survey is Live ‚Äî Every now and then the Go team seeks input from the community to know what to focus on next. The deadline this time is quite short with the survey closing on September 30, so check it out¬†now.

Todd Kulesza and the Go team

IN BRIEF:

  • Next week (Sep 22-26) is one of Go's 'quiet weeks', a period where the Go team largely goes silent, takes a break, or focuses on deep work without¬†interruption. Not a good week for any new language proposals!

  • GitHub's Dependabot now supports Go modules hosted on private registries. Blake Gentry explains more, including why this matters.

GopherCon 2025 Go Contributor Summit Notes ‚Äî Numerous Go contributors came together at the recent GopherCon event to discuss issues including dependency management, the language proposal process, cgo performance, WebAuthn, fuzzing and coverage, WebAssembly as a target (and even the JVM-briefly!), and more. The notes are rough, but flesh out the thinking in many¬†areas.

Google Docs

The Day the Linter Broke My Code ‚Äî Linters don‚Äôt always have all the context when they identify an issue, resulting in cases where an innocuous fix can break your code, forcing you to.. lint your¬†linter?

Oliver Eikemeier

Product for Engineers Newsletter ‚Äî Build better products, not just better code. Learn how to build features users love. Subscribe for¬†free .

PostHog sponsor

üìÑ Using Go Channels to Solve Interface Impedance Mismatch ‚Äì ‚Äúone of the few times in years of Go development that I‚Äôve used channels ‚Ä¶ for a non-concurrent use¬†case‚ÄùZach Musgrave

üìÑ How to Implement the Outbox Pattern in Go and Postgres ‚Äì A resilient way to ensure messages get to where they‚Äôre meant¬†to. Alex Pliutau

üìÑ Building a Simple Stack-Based Virtual Machine in Go ‚Äì Here‚Äôs the¬†code.Phakorn Kiong

üìÑ Observe Live SQL Queries in Go with DTrace Philippe Gaultier

üõ† Code & Tools

Flaggy 1.6: Idiomatic Go Command Line Input Parsing ‚Äî Supports subcommands, positional values, and flags at any position. No external dependencies and doesn‚Äôt insist on a particular project or package layout. v1.6 adds built-in bash/zsh completion generators and drops support for comma separated multi-value¬†arguments.

Eric Greer

graphics.gd: Use Go with the Godot Game Engine ‚Äî Godot is a popular engine for both 2D and 3D games and, despite the name, isn‚Äôt related to Go. This project, however, offers a Go runtime and tooling layer on top of Godot and it can now even be used to create iOS apps in¬†Go.

Quentin Quaadgras

koanf 2.3: Read Configuration with Multiple Sources and Formats ‚Äî Support for JSON, TOML, YAML, environment variables, command line, file, S3 etc. A ‚Äòlighter‚Äô alternative to¬†Viper.

Kailash Nadh

  • Google Gen AI Go SDK v1.25.0 ‚Äì Go SDK for integrating Google's generative AI models including Gemini and Vertex AI into applications.

  • FastHTTP 1.66 ‚Äì Performance-oriented alternative to net/http for specific high-volume¬†scenarios.

  • PSQL Wire Protocol v0.15.0 ‚Äì Pure Go implementation of the Postgres server wire protocol for building custom servers.

  • easyjson 0.9.1 ‚Äì Marshal/unmarshal structs to/from JSON sans reflection.

  • OpenFGA 1.10 ‚Äì Google Zanzibar-inspired authorization¬†engine.

  • River 0.25 ‚Äì Robust job processing system for Go and¬†Postgres.

  • Hugo 0.150.0 ‚Äì The popular static site¬†generator.

  • Goyave 5.9 ‚Äì Opinionated REST API framework.

üì∞¬†Classifieds

Go beyond caching . Redis 8.2 handles 5x more data with 150 new commands and 8 new data structures vs 7.2. Get started¬†today .

üí¨ A Blast from the Past

Retro AIM Server: A Way to Get AIM and ICQ Working Again?‚Äî A curious Go-powered project that provides a self-hosted instant messaging server that classic AOL Instant Messenger and ICQ clients can¬†use. Why? Why¬†not?

mk6i

item.title: Making the Go module proxy happier using a LICENSE file
item.description:
#‚Äã569 ‚Äî September 10, 2025

Read the Web¬†Version

Go Weekly

Let's Look at Go's New Experimental API for JSON ‚Äî Working with the Internet‚Äôs most popular data exchange format is a fundamental, day-to-day task for most developers but Go‚Äôs original json package had enough shortcomings to warrant an attempt at a ‚Äòv2‚Äô which you can use, in experimental form, in Go 1.25. The Go team breaks down the entire story and the behavior of v2 here, but also seeks your¬†feedback.

Tsai, Mart√≠, et al.

üí° Anton Zhiyanov has a more code-driven tour of what json/v2 offers¬†here.

Go with the Domain: DDD & Clean Architecture in¬†Go ‚Äî For Go developers tired of enterprise patterns that don't fit. The Watermill creators show how DDD actually works in Go with code examples from a real¬†application.

Three Dots Labs sponsor

What the Go Proxy Has Been Doing ‚Äî A few weeks ago, Ted asked What is the Go (module) proxy even doing?after he found it hammering his server. He‚Äôs since traded some emails with Russ Cox and discovered some curious things about the proxy‚Äôs behavior, particularly around the contents (and/or lack of) of LICENSE files. This post from Russ Cox himself goes into even more¬†detail.

Ted Unangst

IN BRIEF:

  • The YAML project , official maintainer of the YAML format, has forked and taken over maintenance of the yaml package.

  • üò± Geoffrey Huntley had a single goal: force Claude Code to loop over and over till it built a 'Go like' language based around Gen Z slang , and so Cursed was born.It works, and can even compile to native binaries with¬†LLVM.

  • üé• gocv-to-webrtc offers a demonstration of streaming live webcam video to a browser using GoCV for capture, FFmpeg for real‚Äëtime encoding, and Pion WebRTC for transport.

Avoiding Common sync.WaitGroup Mistakes ‚Äî WaitGroup is easy to misuse, but as of Go 1.25, the go vet tool has extra checks to prevent error-prone calls to WaitGroup.Add , and WaitGroup.Go helps avoid some problems¬†altogether.

Jon Calhoun

Solve Go Bugs and Bottlenecks Quickly with AppSignal ‚Äî Fix Go bugs and bottlenecks fast with AppSignal. Get clear insights and ship reliable code. Start your free trial¬†today .

AppSignal sponsor

üìÑ Running Go-Written Tools in a Browser ‚Äì The ability to compile Go to WebAssembly opens up some fun opportunities on the¬†Web. Uros Popovic

üìÑ 'GoLand Can Do That?' Ten Secret Superpowers You Might Not Know John Arundel

üìÑ Exploring Concurrency Issues with Philosophers and Go Annis Souames

üìÑ Why I Ditched Docker for Podman (And You Should Too)Dominik Szyma≈Ñski

üõ† Code & Tools

ü§ñGoogle Releases Genkit Go 1.0 ‚Äî Genkit Go is Google‚Äôs own open-source AI development framework and it‚Äôs now production ready along with a suite of ancillary tools targeting Go developers building LLM-backed apps (and not just using Google‚Äôs own models). There‚Äôs an introductory tutorial to learn¬†more.

Gill and Balahan (Google)

Ergo 3.1: An Actor-Based Framework for Go ‚Äî A Go-based implementation of ideas and design patterns from the Erlang world. v3.1 introduces a new cron-like scheduler, external process management, and improved testing capabilities. Full docs¬†here.

Taras Halturin

go-getter 1.8: Download Things from Various Sources with a URL ‚Äî So it‚Äôs just an HTTP client? Not exactly. A GitHub URL can become a git URL, local filenames work, S3, Mercurial and BitBucket URLs all work as expected¬†too.

HashiCorp

GoferBroke: An Anti-Entropy Gossip Protocol for Distributed Systems ‚Äî A minimal, high-performance ‚Äògossip‚Äô protocol designed for embedding decentralized, eventually-consistent state into your¬†apps.

Kristian Woodroffe

Kratos 2.9: A Go Framework for Cloud-Based Microservices ‚Äî A ‚Äúmicroservice-oriented governance framework‚Äùbuilt around¬†HTTP/gRPC.

Kratos

üì∞¬†Classifieds

$100 off yearly Frontend Masters membership!250+ courses, personalized learning path, workshops with devs from GitHub & Netflix. Sale ends soon¬†‚Üí

  • csv-go 3.0 ‚Äì A flexible and performant single-threaded CSV stream reader and¬†writer.

  • Anubis 1.22 ‚Äì Provides a proof-of-work challenge to 'weigh the soul' of incoming HTTP requests in an attempt to stop/slow down AI¬†crawlers.

  • Gum 0.17 ‚Äì Go-powered shell scripting¬†utilities by¬†Charm.Now with support for adding visual padding to many of the¬†commands.

  • Viper 1.21 ‚Äì Config solution for Go apps supporting various file formats and environment¬†variables.

  • Listmonk 5.1 ‚Äì Self hosted email newsletter¬†system (homepage ).

  • graphql-go 1.8 ‚Äì GraphQL server with a focus on ease of¬†use.

  • Hugo 0.150 ‚Äì The popular Go-powered static site¬†generator.

  • fx 39.1 ‚Äì The powerful terminal JSON¬†viewer.

  • Air 1.63 ‚Äì Live reload for Go¬†apps.

item.title: Benchmarking Go SQLite libraries
item.description:
#‚Äã568 ‚Äî September 3, 2025

Read the Web¬†Version

Go Weekly

üòéA-go-ha!Gopher Hawaiian Shirt Patterns ‚Äî Humor me for this item in the last gasps of summer! In 2023, Russ Cox worked with Renee French (the creator of the Go gopher mascot ) to design and print some Go-themed Hawaiian shirts. They‚Äôve now made the patterns generally available in several colors. Christmas sweater patterns next,¬†perhaps?

Russ Cox and Renee French

üí° Note that the shirt patterns, and the image above, are all CC-BY-4.0 licensed.

Testing Time (and Other Asynchronicities)‚Äî The official Go blog continues with its tour of new Go features, looking at testing/synctest , newly promoted to general availability in Go 1.25. If you need to write fast, reliable tests for concurrent code, this is a¬†must-read.

Damien Neil

Go Logs with Full Context in¬†Sentry ‚Äî See Go errors, traces, and logs together in one view for complete production context. Debug faster without sifting through logs or switching tools. Find root causes faster, fix problems quickly, and keep your applications running smoothly with¬†Sentry.

Sentry sponsor

Default Methods in Go ‚Äî Go‚Äôs interfaces are simple but can be brittle, particularly when adding a method and having several existing implementations. Miguel digs into some of the limitations and¬†problems.

Miguel Young

IN BRIEF:

  • üîé The latest version of CodeQL, used in GitHub's code scanning system, now supports Go 1.25.

  • Ron Evans of TinyGo has shared his slidedeck from GopherCon 2025 which gives an update on the TinyGo project generally. We look forward to the eventual GopherCon 2025¬†videos!

The 9 Go Test Assertions I Use (and Why)‚Äî Building on an article we linked in issue 562 about avoiding assertion packages, Alex makes a case for his homemade assertions, as well as whether assertion functions are an¬†anti-pattern.

Alex Edwards

üìÑ How Go Schedules Millions of Goroutines: A Deep Dive into¬†GMP RealBlank

üìÑ From Go Code to Container Image with Depot API Chris Goller (Depot)

üìÑ How to Deploy a Hugo Static Site to Hetzner Alex Pliutau

üõ† Code & Tools

Benchmarking Different Go SQLite Drivers (Again)‚Äî A benchmark we‚Äôve linked to a couple of times has seen another update. As with any benchmark results, maintain a critical eye here, but the author found significant differences between the nine options in certain¬†scenarios.

Christoph Vilsmeier

Dedicated Postgres Performance Workshop for Your Team ‚Äî Expert-led workshop on your Postgres database to tune slow queries. New to pganalyze with a large Postgres footprint? This is for you. Request¬†today .

pganalyze sponsor

Announcing GoReleaser v2.12 ‚Äî The popular Go-flavored release crafting tool introduces a new Docker integration, Docker image attestation, Makeself packaging support (to create packages that self-extract/run), Go 1.25, and¬†more.

Carlos Alexandro Becker

Surf: An Advanced HTTP Client Library ‚Äî Has a focus on web scaping and API automation by attempting to impersonate desktop browsers, handle fingerprinting, HTTP/3 support, and¬†more.

enetx

zek: Convert XML into a Go Struct ‚Äî We first linked to this eight years¬†ago.
Martin Czygan

  • GoQueue 0.2.1 ‚Äì Background job processing library, now with support for multiple queueN¬†backends.

  • Pebble 2.1 ‚Äì RocksDB/LevelDB inspired key-value database in Go. Used by CockroachDB under the¬†hood.

  • Garble 0.15 ‚Äì Obfuscation for Go¬†builds. Now with Go 1.25¬†support.

  • gofumpt 0.9 ‚Äì A stricter¬†gofmt . Now based on Go 1.25's¬†gofmt .

  • Revive 1.12 ‚Äì Fast, configurable, extensible, flexible linter for¬†Go.

  • Hugo 0.149 ‚Äì The popular Go-powered static site generator.

  • tview 0.42 ‚Äì Rich interactive widgets for terminal UIs.

  • sqlc 1.30 ‚Äì Generate type-safe Go code from¬†SQL.

‚úâÔ∏è¬† From the Inbox

For a variety of reasons ‚Äì not least taking a vacation in August (oops!) ‚Äì I have a backlog of fantastic submissions from people that I want to share separately:

  • üïπÔ∏è Flappy is a Flappy Bird clone built in Go. It runs cross-platform but isn't Ebitengine based, instead using Prototype which uses Direct3D and OpenGL¬†directly.

  • üìò John Arundel has released a new Go 1.25 edition of his book, The Deeper Love of Go.

  • Making Games in Go: 3 Months Without LLMs vs 3 Days With LLMs is a fun look at one developer's experiences in developing two card games in Go using a variety of technologies.

  • mtlog is a library for producing logs that 'read like prose' but are also structured for machine use. Check out the examples.

  • AgenticGoKit is a new event-driven agentic AI framework, currently in¬†alpha.

  • Przemek Delewski wrote Observability in Go: What Real Engineers Are Saying in¬†2025
